author: Gregory Beyer contributed reporting.
body: THE first guests arrived at 10 p.m., knowing they would dance until nearly dawn. The sari-like Sudanese dress of the women -- called a tob in Arabic -- stood out among the dark suits of the men, and guests shouted to hear one another over the noise of the band. The event, held several weeks ago at the Widdi Catering Hall in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn,
title: BAY RIDGE; For a People in Pain, a Reason to Dance

body: IT was tough for Talima Davis, Brooklyn born and bred, to leave her beloved borough. ''My friends call me the quintessential Brooklyn girl,'' she said. ''I never leave Brooklyn except to go to work.'' But when she found herself priced out of even Bedford-Stuyvesant, she decided she had no choice. When she was growing up, Ms. Davis, 27, lived with
title: THE HUNT; Leaving Brooklyn

body: The M-Punctual driving school, a gray-carpeted shoe box of an office on a side street in Kensington, Brooklyn, has been a bit livelier in recent weeks. More immigrants with questionable documents, or no documents, every one of them a potential customer, have been inquiring about the governor's driver's license proposal. ''For us, it is a great
title: Driving School Students Wait Out the Governor

body: I DON'T own a home. I live under tenuous circumstances in a dilapidated rental apartment in Brooklyn. I still decorate with art from friends, furniture plucked from the street, and piles of books in precarious Dr. Seuss-like stacks. The Home Depot on West 23rd Street in Manhattan, a giant three-floor wedding cake of a space, can be seductive to
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER; Dream Houses and Wishful Thinkers

body: THE Brooklyn real estate market has turned into a bundle of contradictions in recent months. While prices in neighborhoods like Park Slope and Brooklyn Heights soared this summer, so did the number of foreclosures in neighborhoods like Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant. Sorting through these contradictions, buyers are starting to find bargains in a
title: Brooklyn: A Bargain Hunter's Guide

body: THE national median home price right now is $224,500. But finding anything even close to that in New York -- where the average sale price for a Manhattan apartment hovers just above $1.3 million -- would be like snagging a seat on a downtown No. 6 train at the height of rush hour. Or would it? In the current market, staying in Manhattan for
title: Even in New York, Affordable Apartments

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: IF their home could cater to their environmental sensibilities, so much the better. It wasn't that Dara Blumenthal and Darren Patrick expected to find an environmentally friendly apartment, but they did want a big, bright home, ''something that made sense to us, where we could see our energies flowing in and out very naturally,'' Ms. Blumenthal
title: THE HUNT; A Recipe for Success

body: ''I'm still looking, but I want to go away. I'm going to look at Syracuse and Ithaca and Boston and places in D.C. I know I want communications and journalism, but I haven't found a perfect match yet. I want to go to college to experience new things and meet new people. But it's kind of scary to decide about your future.'' Jill Feigelman St.
title: UP AND ABOUT; University Blues

body: A man was indicted on manslaughter charges in the death of a livery cab driver who was run down in the street, prosecutors said yesterday. The cab driver, Rafael Rafailov, 50, had stopped to assist another livery cab driver with a disabled vehicle on Ocean Parkway in Kensington last Wednesday when he was struck and killed by a third car. The driver
title: METRO BRIEFING: NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Charges In Cab Driver Death

body: Christine Marie Terlep, the daughter of Kathleen M. Terlep of Kensington, Md., and the late Vincent B. Terlep Jr., was married yesterday to Dylan John Murphy, the son of Monica D. Murphy and John J. Murphy Jr. of Manhattan. Cardinal Avery Dulles, a Jesuit theologian at Fordham, performed the ceremony at Fordham University Church in the Bronx. Mrs.
title: Christine Terlep, Dylan Murphy

body: WHEN dozens of buyers put down payments on apartments in the glassy new condominium tower called the Link at 310 West 52nd Street, they were looking forward to living with features like floor-to-ceiling windows and a meditation garden. But six months after they started moving in, they are still living in a construction site with an unfinished
title: Condos, Brand-New Yet Not So Perfect

body: A report in the Metro Briefing column in some copies on July 19 about an apparent murder-suicide in Brooklyn misidentified the neighborhood. It was Flatbush, not Kensington.
title: Corrections: For the Record

body: A Brooklyn man fatally shot his wife and then killed himself last night, the police said. The bodies of Monica Cope, 42, and Jonathan Cope, 40, were discovered about 7:30 p.m. at 636 East 21st Street in Kensington, where Ms. Cope lived, the police said. METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK Correction: July 27, 2007, Friday A report in the Metro Briefing
title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Murder-Suicide Suspected

body: The low point in the relationship between United States Postal Service employees and customers in Brooklyn may well have come in late March, when someone videotaped a fellow customer's five-minute, profanity-laced tirade against an employee at the borough's Kensington post office and posted the clip on YouTube. More than a few commenters on the Web
title: Kensington; Talk Therapy for Postal Rage

title: URBAN STUDIES / PROTESTING; Wearing Their Hearts on the Front Window

body: IF they could have predicted the future, Julie and Neil Weintraub would have bought a one-bedroom co-op, not a two-bedroom, for their first home. As their family grew, they began hunting for a larger one. But they let several opportunities pass, reluctant to commit to a new place until they sold their old one. That took more than a year. ''On some
title: THE HUNT; A Crystal Ball Would Have Been Nice

body: MEYERS--Judith Horowitz, of Forest Hills, NY, on May 1, 2007. Loving mother of Jeffrey of Kensington, CA, and the late Kenneth. Cherished grandmother of Rachel. Dearest mother-in-law of Valerie and Ellen Meyers. Entombment Friday, May 4, 2007, at Pinelawn Memorial Park. Services entrusted to McManus Funeral Home, Brooklyn.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths MEYERS, JUDITH HOROWITZ

body: It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single person in New York in possession of a sunlit day must be in want of a companion. Just ask Eric Jacobov, 24, a commercial building developer, who strolled with two friends in Central Park yesterday. ''I like spring,'' he said, lighting a cigarette and peering at sunbathers in the Sheep Meadow.
title: As City Begins Spring Stir, Romance Is in the Air

body: AT the Greenwood Hill Condos, a pair of new buildings in the Greenwood Heights section of Brooklyn, the north-facing apartments have views of the Statue of Liberty and the Manhattan skyline. But the south-facing apartments face the headstone-studded hills of Green-Wood Cemetery across the street. Some people prefer the apartments with the city
title: POSTING; 'Country' Living and Quiet Neighbors

body: Officers arrested two people yesterday morning while investigating two previous thefts at a church in Kensington, the police said. Carmen Sierra, 42, and her brother Juan Sierra, 43, were charged with attempted grand larceny and disruption of a religious service. The police said the two tried to steal money collected during services at the Holy
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Attempted-Larceny Charges

body: Martin A. Trow, a sociologist whose research on higher education reverberated through North America and Europe, particularly his description of the transition of a college education from elite privilege to mass product, died on Feb. 24 at his home in Kensington, Calif. He was 80. The cause was a brain tumor, according to an announcement by the
title: Martin Trow, 80, Sociologist And Higher Education Expert

body: The Masjid Nur al-Islam mosque, on Church Avenue in Kensington, Brooklyn, is a humble two-story brick structure with a green and white sign in Arabic and English. Amid the auto body shops and the Mexican and Middle Eastern restaurants that populate its low-slung corner of the neighborhood, the building barely stands out -- except for the sounds
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KENSINGTON; Calling the Faithful And Getting Complaints

body: Voters in central Brooklyn do not lack for choices in the February 20th special election to fill the City Council seat vacated by Yvette Clarke. A diverse field of 10 candidates is bravely waging a campaign in frigid winter temperatures, each hoping to succeed Ms. Clarke -- now a freshman congresswoman. Considering the size of the field, the off
title: Jesse Hamilton for City Council

body: A deputy mayor and a deputy schools chancellor called a news conference yesterday to reassure parents that they were working hard to solve problems caused by changes to the city's school bus routes this week. At the same time, they said they were sorry for any inconvenience or confusion. Their solicitous tone contrasted with Mayor Michael R.
title: City Tells Parents It Understands As School Bus Crisis Eases a Bit

body: To the Editor: Re ''New York Tries to Think Outside the Sandbox'' (front page, Jan. 10): In the midst of a skyrocketing obesity epidemic among New York children, who have no backyards and very little physical education at school, why would the city build a playground that de-emphasizes running and climbing? title: The Latest Thing in Child's Play
